questions.text: Which layer invades the maternal endometrium and forms the lacunar network for placental-maternal exchange?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The syncytiotrophoblast layer is formed from the trophoblast invades the maternal endometrium.
  • It comes into contact with blood vessels and forms lacunae, spaces filled with maternal blood.
  • This forms the lacunar network that functions in the exchange of nutrients and waste products between the mother and fetus.

During implantation, the trophoblast (outer layer of the blastocyst) differentiates into two layers:

  • Cytotrophoblast is the inner, mitotically active layer.
  • Syncytiotrophoblast is the outer, multinucleated layer without distinct cell boundaries.

Key Role of the Syncytiotrophoblast:

  • Invades the maternal endometrium.
  • Secretes proteolytic enzymes to erode maternal tissues.
  • Creates spaces called lacunae, which eventually become part of the lacunar network.
  • This lacunar system allows maternal blood to mix with fetal trophoblastic tissue, initiating placental-maternal exchange.

Explanation of Other Options:

Blastocyst (Option A):

Key role: Early-stage embryo responsible for initiating implantation

  • The blastocyst is formed around day 5 after fertilization and consists of:
    • Inner cell mass (embryoblast) → becomes the embryo proper
    • Outer cell mass (trophoblast) → gives rise to cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast
  • It is not invasive by itself, but its outer layer (trophoblast) initiates implantation.
  • The blastocyst "hatches" from the zona pellucida before implantation can begin.

Cytotrophoblast (Option B):

Key role: Proliferative layer that gives rise to syncytiotrophoblast

  • The cytotrophoblast is the inner layer of the trophoblast.
  • It contains mononucleated, mitotically active cells that:
    • Proliferate and donate cells to the syncytiotrophoblast.
    • Provide structural support to the growing trophoblast.
  • It does not invade maternal tissues directly.

Endoderm (Option D):

Key role: Forms internal linings and organs during later development

  • The endoderm is one of the three germ layers (along with ectoderm and mesoderm) that arise during gastrulation.
  • It gives rise to the epithelial linings of the:
    • Gastrointestinal tract
    • Respiratory tract
    • Urogenital tract
  • It plays no role in implantation or early placental development.

questions.text: Which layer is acellular, does not expand mitotically, and produces human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which stimulates progesterone production by the corpus luteum? Options:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Syncytiotrophoblast is acellular, does not expand mitotically, and produces human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which stimulates progesterone production by the corpus luteum.
  • B-hCG can be detected in maternal blood as early as day 10 of pregnancy and is part of the pregnancy test.

Clinical Importance:

  • hCG Secretion:
    • Produces human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), the hormone detected in pregnancy tests.
    • hCG maintains the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone to support the early pregnancy.
  • Ectopic Pregnancy Detection:
    • Abnormally low or slowly rising hCG can indicate ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage.
    • Very high hCG may suggest trophoblastic disease (e.g., hydatidiform mole, choriocarcinoma).
  • Placental Invasion:
    • It invades the maternal endometrium to establish the placenta.
    • Abnormal invasion may result in conditions like placenta accreta or increta.
  • Tumor Marker:
    • hCG is a tumor marker for gestational trophoblastic tumors and testicular cancers (seminomas and choriocarcinomas).

Explanation of Other Options:

Cytotrophoblast (Option B):

  • Mitotically active and gives rise to syncytiotrophoblast
  • Does not secrete hCG
  • Cellular layer, not a syncytium

Clinical Importance:

  1. Placental Development:
    • It is the mitotically active layer that regenerates syncytiotrophoblast and contributes to primary chorionic villi.
  2. Chorionic Villi Sampling (CVS):
    • The cytotrophoblast contributes to villi sampled during CVS, a prenatal diagnostic test for genetic abnormalities.
  3. Preeclampsia & IUGR:
    • Impaired cytotrophoblast invasion of maternal spiral arteries can lead to preeclampsia or intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

Epiblast (Option C):

  • Forms the amnion and part of the embryo proper
  • Not involved in implantation or hCG production

Clinical Importance:

  • Origin of the Embryo:
    • All three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm) arise from the epiblast during gastrulation.
    • Errors in this process can lead to gastrulation defects or congenital malformations.
  • Amniotic Cavity Formation:
    • The epiblast forms the floor of the amniotic cavity. Defects here may contribute to amniotic band syndrome.
  • Teratomas:
    • Abnormal epiblast-derived pluripotent cells can cause sacrococcygeal teratomas, the most common tumor in newborns.

Endoderm (Option D):

  • Forms the gut tube and yolk sac lining
  • Does not contribute to trophoblast or hormone secretion

Clinical Importance:

  • Forms Internal Organs:
    • Gives rise to the gastrointestinal tract, liver, pancreas, lungs, and bladder lining.
    • Malformations of these organs often trace back to endodermal defects.
  • Cysts and Fistulas:
    • Improper development or separation of endodermal structures (e.g., tracheoesophageal fistula) can cause congenital anomalies.
  • Yolk Sac Tumors:
    • Derived from endodermal tissues, yolk sac tumors (especially in the testis/ovary) are malignant germ cell tumors seen in children.

choices.text: Endoderm of the roof of the yolk sac and embryonic ectoderm
A spherical area of endoderm fused to embryonic mesoderm
The prochordal plate and the overlying embryonic endoderm

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Once the mesodermal layer has formed, the only places at which the ectoderm and endoderm are in direct apposition are the prochordal plate cranially and the cloacal membrane caudally.
  • In these areas, the embryonic ectoderm is fused with the endoderm of the roof of the yolk sac.
  • The cloacal membrane is a bilaminar structure that forms at the caudal (tail) end of the embryo. It marks the future site of the anus and urogenital openings.
  • There is no intervening mesoderm at this site.

Explanation of Other Options:

Embryonic endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm(Option A): The cloacal membrane lacks mesoderm, it is only bilaminar, not trilaminar.

A spherical area of endoderm fused to embryonic mesoderm(Option C): Cloacal membrane does not involve mesoderm, and it is flat, not spherical.

The prochordal plate and the overlying embryonic endoderm(Option D): Describes the oropharyngeal membrane, not the cloacal membrane.

choices.text: Between the inner cell mass and the trophoblast

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The amniotic cavity forms between the epiblast (part of the inner cell mass) and the overlying cytotrophoblast (from the trophoblast).(Option B ruled out)
  • This happens around day 8 of development.(Option A ruled out)
  • The amniotic cavity is a fluid-filled space that forms early in the second week of development.
  • It eventually surrounds the entire embryo and fetus, protecting it throughout pregnancy.(Option D ruled out)

Functions of the Amniotic Cavity:

  • Cushions the embryo/fetus from mechanical shocks
  • Allows free movement and growth
  • Prevents adhesions between the embryo and surrounding tissues
  • Maintains a constant temperature
  • Supports lung and limb development

Abnormalities in the formation of the amniotic cavity or its fluid (amniotic fluid) can lead to conditions like:

  • Oligohydramnios (too little fluid)
  • Polyhydramnios (too much fluid)
  • Amniotic band syndrome (fibrous bands restricting development)

choices.text: Extraembryonic coelom surrounds the yolk sac

questions.text: Which statement about the 14-day blastocyst is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primary villi begin forming around day 13, as cytotrophoblast cells proliferate and penetrate the syncytiotrophoblast.
  • Syncytiotrophoblast extends processes into the endometrium at the end of the 1st week, and spaces called lacunae or sinusoids appear within this syncytium during the 2nd week. (Option C ruled out)
  • Maternal blood leaking into the lacunae initiates uteroplacental circulation. Primary villi form near the end of 2 weeks as cytotrophoblast invades syncytium.
  • By day 14, the extraembryonic coelom (chorionic cavity) surrounds the secondary yolk sac except where the connecting stalk anchors the embryo.(Option B ruled out)

choices.text: By the end of the first week
By erosion of the myometrial lining

questions.text: The completion of interstitial implantation, so that the conceptus is entirely within the endometrium, occurs:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Interstitial implantation is the process by which the blastocyst embeds completely into the endometrium (lining of the uterus), becoming surrounded by maternal tissue.

  • This process begins around days 6-7 after fertilization.
  • By day 9, the syncytiotrophoblast has extended deeper into the endometrium.
  • By day 11, implantation is complete: the conceptus is fully embedded within the endometrium, and the surface epithelium is regenerated over it.

Implantation is the process by which the blastocyst attaches to and embeds into the endometrium, the lining of the uterus. It typically occurs between days 6-10 after fertilization, during the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.

Explanation of Other Options:

On about day 20 (Option A): By day 20 (approx. 6 days post-implantation), the placenta is already forming.

By the end of the first week (Option C): At the end of the first week (~day 7), the blastocyst is only partially embedded.

By erosion of the myometrial lining (Option D): Implantation occurs within the endometrium, not by eroding into the myometrium (muscle layer of the uterus). Invasion into the myometrium is abnormal and associated with placenta accreta or ectopic implantation.

questions.text: The definitive yolk sac of the embryo appears by what day?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Around the 13th day, the definitive yolk sac is formed by the hypoblast cells that line the inside of the exocoelomic membrane.

Primary yolk sac (exocoelomic cavity)

  • Forms around day 9 from hypoblast cells lining the blastocoel.
  • Temporarily serves as the yolk sac but is soon displaced.

Definitive yolk sac (secondary yolk sac)

  • Forms by day 13 as the primary yolk sac pinches off, leaving a smaller cavity lined by new hypoblast-derived cells.
  • This is the yolk sac seen in ultrasound and is functionally important in:
    • Early hematopoiesis
    • Nutrient transfer
    • Primordial germ cell migration
  • Gradually shrinks as the placenta takes over the role of nutrition
  • By the end of the first trimester, it becomes vestigial or may persist as a small cyst

questions.text: What process converts the bilaminar disc into the trilaminar embryonic disc consisting of ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrulation is the process that converts epiblast from a bilaminar disc into a trilaminar embryonic disc, consisting of the three main layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.

Begins in the third week of development (~day 15-16).

The primitive streak appears in the epiblast.

Epiblast cells migrate inward (invaginate) at the primitive streak and differentiate into:

  • Endoderm (replaces hypoblast)
  • Mesoderm (migrates between epiblast and endoderm)
  • The remaining epiblast becomes ectoderm

Explanation of Other Options:

Somitogenesis (Option A): Formation of somites (blocks of mesoderm that form vertebrae and skeletal muscle). Occurs after gastrulation.

Transformation (Option B): Refer to general cellular changes, but not specific to trilaminar disc formation

Neurulation (Option D): Formation of the neural tube from ectoderm is called neurulation. Occurs after gastrulation. Involves only the ectodermal layer.

questions.text: At the end of the third week, somites begin to develop along the notochord and neural tube. What do they end up forming?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paraxial mesoderm that forms along the notochord and neural tube divides and forms paired cuboidal bodies called somites starting in week three.
  • They develop in a caudal direction from day 20-30 and give rise to most of the axial skeleton (skull base, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum), all skeletal musculature, and the dermis of the skin.
  • They are critical in the segmentation and development of the embryo.
  • Somites differentiate into three major components:

Explanation of Other Options:

Brain (Option B): Develops from the anterior neural tube, not somites.

Spinal cord (Option C): Arises from the neural tube, not somites.

Sympathetic chain ganglia (Option D): Derive from neural crest cells, not from somites.

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from the splanchnic layer of the lateral plate mesoderm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lining of the gut is endodermal in origin, but the smooth muscle of the gut forms from the splanchnic layer of the lateral plate mesoderm.
  • The visceral peritoneum also forms from the splanchnic mesoderm, but the parietal layers of the serous membranes (peritoneum, pleura, pericardium) form from the somatic layer of the lateral plate mesoderm.

The splanchnic (visceral) layer of the lateral plate mesoderm contributes to the formation of structures surrounding the endoderm-lined gut tube, including:

  • Smooth muscle
  • The connective tissue of the gastrointestinal tract
  • Cardiac muscle
  • Visceral layers of serous membranes (peritoneum, pleura, pericardium)

Explanation of Other Options:

Enamel of the teeth (Option A): Derived from oral ectoderm, specifically ameloblasts.

Mucous lining of the larynx (Option C): Derived from the endoderm of the foregut.

Sympathetic chain ganglia (Option D): Derived from neural crest cells, which are ectodermal in origin.
Explanation:

questions.text: The following are four structures together with a germ layer. Identify the incorrect association:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The epithelium of the pancreas and lung is endodermal, indicating an origin from the primitive gut. (Option A ruled out.)

Hair is ectodermal in origin. Bone arises primarily from mesoderm, although there is neural crest contribution to the bone of the face. ( Option B ruled out)

The heart is mesodermal also. (Option C ruled out.)

questions.text: Of the following, which is derived from endoderm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tonsils arise from the endodermal epithelium lining the 2nd pharyngeal pouch.

Kidneys & gonads arise from intermediate mesoderm. (Option B and C ruled out.)

Skeletal muscle is from somites and somitomeres. Cardiac & most smooth muscle is from splanchnic mesoderm. The neural crest develops some vascular smooth muscle. ( Option A ruled out.)

Pharyngeal pouches are endoderm-lined outpocketings of the pharyngeal (branchial) foregut that develop between the pharyngeal arches during embryogenesis. Each pouch gives rise to specific structures in the head and neck.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is believed to be a primary organizer or inducer during organogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The notochord is considered a crucial structure in the induction of organogenic events.

The primary embryonic organizer. It induces the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate (which later forms the neural tube and CNS). It also patterns surrounding mesodermal tissues and influences somite differentiation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Somites (Option A):

  • Blocks of paraxial mesoderm that segment along the embryo’s length.
  • Somites differentiate into the sclerotome (vertebrae and ribs), myotome (skeletal muscles), and dermatome (dermis of skin).
  • They do not act as primary organizers. They are important for segmental patterning but generally respond to signals rather than induce major organ formation.

Metanephric blastema (Option C):

  • Mesenchymal tissue that gives rise to the definitive adult kidney (metanephros).
  • Interacts reciprocally with the ureteric bud during kidney development, inducing branching morphogenesis.
  • It is an inductive tissue in kidney organogenesis, but not a primary organizer of the embryo.

Lens placode (Option D):

  • Thickening of the surface ectoderm above the optic vesicle.
  • Induced by the optic vesicle to form the lens of the eye.
  • It is a responding tissue; the lens placode does not act as a primary organizer but is induced by other structures.

questions.text: The following organs are derived from mesoderm EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The suprarenal or adrenal medulla is a part of the sympathetic nervous system. Therefore, it is a derivative of neural crest cells, and neural crest cells are ectodermal in origin.

Explanation of Other Options:

Musculature of blood vessels (Option A): Specifically, from the lateral plate mesoderm (splanchnic layer), which gives rise to smooth muscle of blood vessels.

Cardiac musculature (Option B): Originates from the splanchnic mesoderm of the lateral plate, which forms the heart and its musculature.

Suprarenal (adrenal) cortex (Option C): Comes from the intermediate mesoderm, which also gives rise to the urogenital structures.
